Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter AS is probably the right choice at this stage of you diagnosis. Your PSA is low and only 1 core 5% positive with G(3+3). You have plenty of time to watch and monitor to see if your cancer is indolent and if so no treatment is needed. You also want to get a couple of books , e.g., Dr. Walsh's book, on prostate cancer to gain some additional insights so you will become an informed patient. The other thing you should do is to send the biopsy slides to a prominent lab, e.g. Johns Hopkins, for a second opinion since the G(3+3) is often the judgement of the pathologist who examined your slides. You want to make sure the 3+3 is not a 3+4. Good luck. ____ The DRE did not detect any abnormalities. I will follow suggestions on board for second opinion on the slides. About to have colonoscopy that is due (4-5 year intervals). Physician says there are not risks of that impacting prostate biopsy area. Would it be standard practice to get "body scan" to see if cancer elsewhere?

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 10 days ago, insights sought

Posts.Content: Age 55 PSA of 3.8 Biopsy results on 3/8 16 cores 1 positive, 5 pct of core tissue, .2cm: right apex prostate adenocarcinoma Gleason 6 (3,3) 15 cores negative (2 right base, 4 right mid prostate, 1 right apex, 2 left base, 4 left mid prostate, 2 left apex) Active surveillance suggested with psa again in 3 mo interval and next biopsy in a year. Weighing this versus prostate removal. Would appreciate suggestions from others on this.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 10 days ago, insights sought

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fasteddie paulplus, sorry to hear that you are a member of the club. Your stats indicate that you are in the early stage of prostate cancer. I would encourage you to get a copy of "The Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Walsh. Read it cover to cover and you will have a better understanding of your condition. During your DRE did the urologist feel a nodule or an area of hardness? You definitely have time to research your next step. You may want to get a second opinion from a cancer center that specializes in prostate cancer. This would help you confirm active surveillance as an option. You will need to send your slides to them ahead of time with the pathology report. You need to know that 30%of the time the Gleason score is higher than the biopsy indicates. Keep us posted on updates. I am sure a number of more informed member will respond. Peace and Grace Ed Thanks you for the book suggestion. Will order tonite. No issues found during DRE
